@input recordsLimit @output Array of json object Please provide recordsLimit as input variable while configuring script in card mapping script.ex:getAllRecords(recordsLimit);
Example: 
{
    'badge': '',
    'badgeColor': '',
    'image': '',
    'title': '',
    'description': '',
    'field1Label': '',
    'field1Value': '',
    'field2Label': '',

    'itemUrl': '',
    'sortFieldValue': '',
    'target': '' // target is '' if its internal or portal page url. target is '_blank' if url is external

                    'parentTable': '',
                    'parentRecordSysId': '',
                    'actionGrpSysId': ''
                }

Search Sort Options Description
UI Policy Form Description

Configuration

  • Name: The name of the Facet record.

  • Label: The label of the Facet displayed on the UI.

  • Facet Field: The string which corresponds to the field on which the facet is based. If one wants to filter search results by names of users, we can create a facet for the names field in the sys_user table. The field must belong to a table defined in the Search Profile's sources. The string must be in the format [table name].[field name] . If either of these conditions are unmet the system will display a warning and prevent submission.

    Note: Fields of the following types, with a relatively low number of unique values, make the best facets: True/False, Choice, Reference, String, and String (Full UTF-8). Fields with numeric or date values are not recommended for use as facets.

  • Facet Value Limit: The maximum number of facet values to be displayed on the UI under the facet.

  • Order: The order of the facet displayed on the UI. The lower the value, the higher it appears on the facet list UI.

  • Active: Determines if the facet is active or not.

Attention

  • Do not add time-consuming code in scripted processor, otherwise it will slow down the entire search experience. It is because each search result record will go through the processor.
  • Optimize your code by returning as soon as it can. For example, if the search result table does not match the processor's target table, you can return without unnecessary code execution.

Info Message
Permissions evaluation process: Evaluation process is carried out by impersonating a user and determining the ACL permission on the resource. Permission rules allow access to the specified resource if all three of these checks evaluate to true:
1. Access Handlers must evaluate to “Passed”, or is empty/undefined
2. Data filters must evaluate to “Passed”, or is empty/undefined
3. Access control rules (ACLs) evaluates to “Passed”
The three checks are evaluated independently in the order displayed above.

MID k8s deployment request help

Search Facet

Search Facets are filters which pertain exclusively to the results of a search. In contrast to Navigation Tab filters which are static between searches, Facets relate specifically to the executed search query. This means different facets are displayed depending on what your query is, and what the returned results are. Any field in a table that is defined in the Search Profile's sources can become a facet.

Use this form to create and configure Search Facets for a certain Search Application Configuration. Please note if the Search Profile for a search application is updated, some records may need to be updated.

Genius Result Record Object APIs

  • isSearchBased(): return a boolean that tells if the genius record is search-based (only has request processor script)
  • getModelId(): return model_id of the genius record.
  • setModelId(modelId): set model_id to the genius record.
  • getFields(): return the list of field objects. Field Object APIs are listed below in a separate section.
  • getField(fieldName): return the field with the given name, if available, else returns null.
  • addField(fieldName, label, value, displayValue): add a new field to the search record.

Field Object APIs

  • getName(): return field name.
  • setName(name): set name to the field.
  • getLabel(): return field label.
  • setLabel(label): set label to the field.
  • getValue(): return field value (value and displayValue are the same in most cases, except for reference field, where value is sys_id, displayValue is the display value of the referenced record.
  • setValue(value): set value to the field.
  • getDisplayValue(): return field value.
  • setDisplayValue(displayValue): set displayValue to the field.

Search Result Record Object APIs

  • getSysId(): return sys_id of the search record.
  • setSysId(sys_id): set sys_id to the search record.
  • getTable(): return table of the search record (same as the table in requested fields).
  • setTable(table): set table to the search record.
  • getUrl(): return url of the search record
  • setUrl(url): set url to the search record.
  • getRecordClassName(): return the actual child table of the search record.
  • setRecordClassName(recordClassName): set recordClassName to the search record.
  • getScore(): return the relevancy score of the search record.
  • setScore(score): set the relevancy score to the search record.
  • getDocumentType(): return the document type of the search record (if applicable).
  • getTitle(): return the teaser title provided by AI search engine.
  • setTitle(title): set the teaser title to the search record.
  • getText(): return the teaser text provided by AI search engine.
  • setText(text): set the teaser text to the search record.
  • getTableLabelSingular(): return the table sigular label.
  • setTableLabelSingular(label): set the table sigular label to the search record.
  • getTableLabelPlural(): return the table plural label.
  • setTableLabelPlural(label): set the table plural label to the search record.
  • getField(fieldName): return the field with the given name, if available, else returns null.
  • getFields(): return the list of field objects. Field Object APIs are listed below in a separate section.
  • addField(fieldName, label, value, displayValue): add a new field to the search record.
  • getFileExtension(): return file extension of the search record (if applicable).
  • setFileExtension(extension): set file extension to the search record.
  • getParentTitle(): return parent record title of the search record (if applicable).
  • setParentTitle(): set parent title to the search record.
  • getParentSysId(): return parent record sys_id of the search record (if applicable).
  • setParentSysId(): set parent sys_id to the search record.

Field Object APIs

  • getName(): return field name.
  • setName(name): set name to the field.
  • getLabel(): return field label.
  • setLabel(label): set label to the field.
  • getValue(): return field value (value and displayValue are the same in most cases, except for reference field, where value is sys_id, displayValue is the display value of the referenced record.
  • setValue(value): set value to the field.
  • getDisplayValue(): return field value.
  • setDisplayValue(displayValue): set displayValue to the field.
When to Apply

Define who needs to approve the item before it can be fulfilled.
The following types of approval can be selected:
  • User
    A specific person that must respond to the approval request
  • Group
    A group of people. The first person's response from the group will be used
  • Predefined Approval
    Additional options that have been defined by your administrator For example, to request approval from the manager of the item requestor
The Order field determines the sequence in which approvals will be requested. If multiple approvals have the same order number they will be requested at the same time.

AI Search for Next Experience

From here, one can begin and monitor the migration of Polaris-enabled search applications from Zing to the new AI Search technology.

Step 1: Convert Zing search applications

In this step, the Search Applications listed below will be converted from Zing to AI Search, and any necessary Indexed Sources, Search Profiles, Dictionaries will be created.

Step 2: Index Content

In this step, the Indexed Sources created in the previous step will be indexed. You'll be able to monitor the progress of the indexing and receive a notification when the process is finished and all content is searchable.

Step 3: Complete migration to AI Search

In this final step, we'll activate AI Search for all of the Next Experience Search Applications.

These advanced options are designated for Reverse MID servers. Reverse MID servers are unique topologies, reserved for on-premise installations only, that for some reasons (mainly for security issues) do not allow the communication from MID to its instance, and requires the instance to initiate the communication to the MID. For more information please read More Info.

Similarity Score is a measure (0-100) for the degree of similarity between two records. Records with a similarity score higher than the threshold below will be returned by this solution. Review similarity examples and their scores on the related link below to determine whether to increase/decrease solution threshold. You can change the value in the Similarity Score Threshold field. Note: The Similarity Window filter conditions on the solution definition are not applied for similarity examples.
